The subway platform reeked of decay and broken dreams, much like Brooklyn herself as she crouched in the shadows beneath the Williamsburg Bridge. Her massive frame, once human but now something far more grotesque, trembled with each wave of regret that coursed through her transformed body. The fluorescent lights flickered overhead, casting dancing shadows that seemed to mock her very existence.

She remembered when she was different. When she was Sarah Chen, a bright-eyed architecture student with plans to rebuild the city's forgotten neighborhoods. That was before the accident, before the experimental treatment, before the rage and guilt twisted her into something unrecognizable. Now she was Brooklyn—a name whispered in terror throughout the borough that had once been her home.

The young man stumbled down the platform, headphones blasting music loud enough that he couldn't hear her approach. He was probably twenty-two, maybe twenty-three, with the kind of careless confidence that reminded Brooklyn of her younger brother. The brother she'd failed to save. The brother whose death had driven her to volunteer for Dr. Kellerman's experimental regenerative therapy program.

Her massive hands, each finger thick as a tree branch, flexed involuntarily. The regret feeding her transformation whispered sweet poison in her ears. "He looks just like Danny, doesn't he? Just like your brother before the overdose. Before you were too busy with your career to notice the signs."

The young man turned, finally sensing her presence. His eyes widened in horror as he took in her hulking form—easily nine feet tall now, with mottled gray-green skin that seemed to pulse with its own malevolent life. Her face, while still vaguely human, had stretched and warped until it resembled something from humanity's darkest nightmares.

"Please," he whispered, backing against the tiled wall. "I have a family. A girlfriend. We're supposed to—"

Brooklyn's voice came out as a guttural rasp, barely recognizable as human speech. "So did my brother. So did I." The regret surged through her again, and she felt her body grow another few inches, muscles bulging with unnatural strength. "But families fail each other, don't they? People always fail."

She grabbed him before he could scream, her enormous hands wrapping around his torso like a vise. The transformation had not only changed her body but had awakened something predatory and ritualistic within her twisted psyche. She needed them to understand—needed their friends and family to feel the same crushing weight of loss that consumed her every waking moment.

The act itself was swift but deliberate. When it was over, she carefully collected what she needed, her movements methodical despite the monstrous rage that had just consumed her. She'd learned to be precise in her grotesque ritual. The toes—a symbol of the paths these young men would never walk, the journeys they'd never complete.

From his wallet, she extracted his phone, scrolling through his contacts with surprising delicacy given the size of her fingers. The device looked like a child's toy in her massive hands. She found what she was looking for: recent messages, frequent contacts, people who would be expecting to hear from him.

Back in her lair—an abandoned subway tunnel that the city had forgotten decades ago—Brooklyn prepared her message. The space was a monument to her former life, filled with architectural drawings and models of buildings she'd never design. She'd learned to use technology despite her transformation, adapting to the modern world's methods of communication even as she'd rejected its humanity.

She photographed her grisly trophy carefully, ensuring the image was clear but not immediately identifiable. Then she began typing, hunting and pecking with one massive finger on the tiny keyboard.

"Your friend thought about you at the end. Thought about all the ways you failed him, just like I failed mine. This is what remains when the walking stops. When the dreams die. When the people who should have cared look the other way. More will follow until everyone understands."

She sent the image to five different contacts from the victim's phone—friends, family members, his girlfriend whose name appeared most frequently in his messages. Then she destroyed the device, crushing it to electronic powder between her palms.

The ritual complete, Brooklyn retreated deeper into her tunnel, where the darkness matched the void in her soul. But even as she tried to find some momentary peace, the regret was already building again, feeding on itself, growing stronger. The experimental treatment had bonded with her guilt and rage in ways Dr. Kellerman had never anticipated. Each act of violence only amplified her need for more, creating a vicious cycle that she was powerless to break.

Miles away, Detective Sarah Painter was just finishing her shift when the first call came in. She'd seen plenty of disturbing cases since transferring from Regina to New York, but something about the panicked voice on the dispatcher's radio made her blood run cold.

"We've got reports of a... I don't know how to classify this. Multiple individuals have received photographs of human remains via text message. The images appear to be connected to a missing persons report filed this morning."

Sarah grabbed her jacket and badge, her instincts telling her this was going to be unlike anything she'd encountered before. She'd always been good at seeing patterns, at understanding the twisted logic that drove people to commit unthinkable acts. It was a skill that had served her well during her years in Saskatchewan, where she'd tracked down serial killers across the vast prairies.

But as she drove through Brooklyn's winding streets toward the first victim's apartment, she couldn't shake the feeling that she was about to confront something that would challenge everything she thought she knew about human nature.

The girlfriend, Jessica Martinez, was inconsolable when Sarah arrived.
